sen.j: 壬生狂言（みぶきょうげん）は、毎年節分と4月、10月に京都市 中京区の壬生寺（みぶでら）で演じられる無言劇である。
sen.e: Mibu Kyogen is a form of farcilcal drama perfored at the Mibu-dera Temple in Kyot every year at the time of the Setsubun Festiveal (February), in April, and October coinciding with the annual cycle of Noh performances.

Mibu Kyogen is a form of farcilcal drama perfored at the Mibu-dera Temple in Kyot every year at the time of the Setsubun Festiveal (February), in April, and October coinciding with the annual cycle of Noh performances.

Mibu Kyogen is a form of pantomime skits performed at the Mibu-dera Temple in Kyoto every year at the time of the Setsubun Festival (February), in April, and October coinciding with the annual cycle of Noh performances.
sen.cmt: farcilcal drama→pantomime skits に変更スペル

sen.j: 大念仏狂言（だいねんぶつきょうげん）のひとつ。
sen.e: It is a form of Dainenbutsu Kyogen.
It is a form of Dainenbutsu Kyogen.
It is a form of Dainenbutsu Kyogen.

sen.j: 重要無形民俗文化財に指定されている。
sen.e: It has been designated as an significant intangible folk cultural asset.
It has been designated as an significant intangible folk cultural asset.
It has been designated as an significant intangible folk cultural asset.

sen.j: 概要
sen.e: Overview
Overview
Summary

sen.j: 仮面をつけた演者が、鉦、太鼓、笛の囃子に合わせ、無言で演じる。
sen.e: The performers wear masks during the performace and have no spoken parts, ans are acompanied by a small instrumental ensemble including a flute, a drum, and a mouth organ (the ensemble is called a "hayashi").

The performers wear masks during the performace and have no spoken parts, ans are acompanied by a small instrumental ensemble including a flute, a drum, and a mouth organ (the ensemble is called a "hayashi").

The performers wear masks during the performance and have no spoken parts, and are accompanied by a small instrumental ensemble including a gong, a drum, and a Japanese flute (the ensemble is called a "hayashi").
sen.cmt: スペルa flute, a drum, and a mouth organ→a gong, a drum, and a Japanese fluteに変更

sen.j: 演目は全部で30ある。
sen.e: There are thirty pieces in the Mibu Kyogen repertoire.
There are thirty pieces in the Mibu Kyogen repertoire.
There are thirty pieces in the Mibu Kyogen repertoire.

sen.j: 演目には、勧善懲悪などの教訓を伝える話や平家物語、御伽草子に取材した話などがある。
sen.e: The pieces include many that are based on tales of historical figures, and serve as vehicles of transmitting a variety of traditional teachings.
The pieces include many that are based on tales of historical figures, and serve as vehicles of transmitting a variety of traditional teachings.
The pieces include many that are based on The Tale of the Heike, the Otogi Zoshi, and other moral tales that serve as vehicles of transmitting a variety of traditional teachings.

sen.j: 煎餅を観客席に投げる（愛宕詣り）、紙でできた糸を観客席に投げる（土蜘蛛）、綱渡りをする（鵺）、素焼きの皿を割る（炮烙割り）といった派手な見せ場を持つ演目もある。
sen.e: The repertoire includes a number of pieces that involve the audience in a highly tactile manner, including a piece in which senbei rice crackers are tossed to spectators in the audience Atago mairi (Pilgrimage to Mount Atago), a piece in which paper ropes are thrown into the audience ???(???), a piece in which there is a tightrope walking scene ???(???), and a piece in which pottery plates are smashed Horaku wari (Smashing Plates).

The repertoire includes a number of pieces that involve the audience in a highly tactile manner, including a piece in which senbei rice crackers are tossed to spectators in the audience Atago mairi (Pilgrimage to Mount Atago), a piece in which paper ropes are thrown into the audience ???(???), a piece in which there is a tightrope walking scene ???(???), and a piece in which pottery plates are smashed Horaku wari (Smashing Plates).

The repertoire includes a number of pieces that involve the audience in a highly tactile manner, including a piece in which senbei rice crackers are tossed to spectators in the audience Atago mairi (Pilgrimage to Mount Atago), a piece in which paper ropes are thrown into the audience Tsuchigumo (The Demon Spider), a piece in which there is a tightrope walking scene Nue (Nightmare Bird), and a piece in which pottery plates are smashed Horaku wari (Smashing Plates).

sen.j: 壬生狂言を伝承し演じるのは、壬生大念仏講中の人々である。
sen.e: The performer of Mibu Kyogen are all members of the Mibu Dainenbutsu Association.
The performer of Mibu Kyogen are all members of the Mibu Dainenbutsu Association.
The performer of Mibu Kyogen are all members of the Mibu Dainenbutsu Association.

sen.j: 地元の小学生から長老まで約40人が壬生大念仏講中を構成し、学校通い、会社勤め、商いなどの本職のかたわらに練習をし、公演をしている。
sen.e: The Mibu Dainenbutsu Association if formed from approximately 40 members, spanning a wide age group from local elementary school students to senior citizens, who take time out from their normal occupations as commuting students, slaried employees, running small business and the like to reherse and perform.

The Mibu Dainenbutsu Association if formed from approximately 40 members, spanning a wide age group from local elementary school students to senior citizens, who take time out from their normal occupations as commuting students, slaried employees, running small business and the like to reherse and perform.

The Mibu Dainenbutsu Association is formed from approximately 40 members, spanning a wide age group from local elementary school students to senior citizens, who take time out from their normal occupations as commuting students, salaried employees, running small business and the like to rehearse and perform.

sen.j: 公演は毎年3回である。
sen.e: There are three public performances per year.
There are three public performances per year.
There are three public performances per year.

sen.j: 2月の節分前日と当日の2日間 節分会（せつぶんえ）
sen.e: During February there is a series of performance during the Setsubun holiday (Bean Throwing Festival), called the Setsubun-e, which starts on the day before Setsubun, with the final performace on the day of the Setsubun Festival.

During February there is a series of performance during the Setsubun holiday (Bean Throwing Festival), called the Setsubun-e, which starts on the day before Setsubun, with the final performace on the day of the Setsubun Festival.

During February there is a series of performance during the Setsubun holiday (Bean Throwing Festival), called the Setsubun-e, which starts on the day before Setsubun, with the final performance on the day of the Setsubun Festival.

sen.j: 4月21日から4月29日までの9日間 大念仏会（だいねんぶつえ）
sen.e: In April there is a series of performances that spans nine days from the 21st through the 29th, called the Dainenbutsu-e.
In April there is a series of performances that spans nine days from the 21st through the 29th, called the Dainenbutsu-e.
In April there is a series of performances that spans nine days from the 21st through the 29th, called the Dainenbutsu-e.

sen.j: 10月の体育の日までの3日間 秋の特別公開
sen.e: In October there is a special series of performaces spanning three days ending on Sports Day.
In October there is a special series of performaces spanning three days ending on Sports Day.
In October there is a special series of performances spanning three days ending on Sports Day.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代の1300年、融通念仏の円覚上人によって創始されたと伝えられている融通念仏の狂言。
sen.e: According to legend, the Yuzunebutsu Kyogen was created during the Kamakura Period around the year 1300 by Yuzunenbutsu priest Engaku Shonin.
According to legend, the Yuzunebutsu Kyogen was created during the Kamakura Period around the year 1300 by Yuzunenbutsu priest Engaku Shonin.
According to legend, the Yuzunenbutsu Kyogen was created during the Kamakura period around the year 1300 by Yuzunenbutsu priest Engaku Shonin.

sen.j: メガホンのない時代に、仏教を群衆にわかりやすく説くために、大げさな身ぶり手ぶりで表現する無言劇の形態が採用されたという。
sen.e: It is said that in an era during which there were no megaphones and the like, he sought to spread Buddhist teachings to the populus through a form of silent drama using exagerated movements and gestures.

It is said that in an era during which there were no megaphones and the like, he sought to spread Buddhist teachings to the populus through a form of silent drama using exagerated movements and gestures.

It is said that in an era during which there were no megaphones and the like, he sought to spread Buddhist teachings to the populous through a form of easy to understand silent drama using exaggerated movements and gestures.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ対応しました。スペル

sen.j: 念仏狂言が無言劇化した理由については、本来、大衆が念仏をする前で行なわれたものであったために、台詞を発しても念仏の声にかき消されて伝わらないので無言になったとする説もある。
sen.e: The reason for making Nenbutsu Kyogen a silent form of dramatic art is because it was originally performed before a large gathering of people were to perform a Nenbutsu chant, so that even if the plays did include dialog it might become drowned out by the chanting.

The reason for making Nenbutsu Kyogen a silent form of dramatic art is because it was originally performed before a large gathering of people were to perform a Nenbutsu chant, so that even if the plays did include dialog it might become drowned out by the chanting.

According to one interpretation, the reason that Nenbutsu Kyogen was made into a silent form of dramatic art was because it had originally been performed before a large gathering of people who were to chant the Nenbutsu, so that even if the plays did include dialog it might become drowned out by the chanting.

sen.j: なお、同じ念仏狂言でも、引接寺 (京都市)のものは、台詞入りで行なわれている。
sen.e: Note that there is another form of Nenbutsu Kyogen perofmed at Injo-ji Temple (Kyoto City) that does include dialog.
Note that there is another form of Nenbutsu Kyogen perofmed at Injo-ji Temple (Kyoto City) that does include dialog.
Note that there is another form of Nenbutsu Kyogen performed at Injo-ji Temple (Kyoto City) that does include dialog.

sen.j: 江戸時代になると、布教活動としての色彩が薄れ、大衆娯楽として発展した。
sen.e: During the Edo Period the role of the Nenbutsu Kyogen as a vehicle for spreading Buddhist teachings gradually became diluted, with the Kyogen taking on more of a form of entertainment for the masses.
During the Edo Period the role of the Nenbutsu Kyogen as a vehicle for spreading Buddhist teachings gradually became diluted, with the Kyogen taking on more of a form of entertainment for the masses.
During the Edo period the role of the Nenbutsu Kyogen as a vehicle for spreading Buddhist teachings gradually became diluted, with the Kyogen taking on more of a form of entertainment for the masses.

sen.j: 能や狂言、物語に取材し、新しい演目が考案された。
sen.e: Whether Noh or Kyogen, many new pieces were drasn up during this period, taking their material from old tales and legends.
Whether Noh or Kyogen, many new pieces were drasn up during this period, taking their material from old tales and legends.
Many new pieces were drawn up during this period, taking their material from Noh, Kyogen and old tales.
sen.cmt: スペル原文赤字部分は「能や狂言、物語の３つに取材し」という意味に解釈し、修正しました。

sen.j: 愛宕詣り（あたごまいり） ※ 但し、本来は壬生寺ではなく清凉寺の演目。
sen.e: Atago mairi (Pilgrimage to Mount Atago) Note that this piece was not originally performed at Mibu-dera Temple, but at Seiryo-ji Temple
Atago mairi (Pilgrimage to Mount Atago) Note that this piece was not originally performed at Mibu-dera Temple, but at Seiryo-ji Temple
Atago mairi (Pilgrimage to Mount Atago) Note that this piece was not originally performed at Mibu-dera Temple, but at Seiryo-ji Temple

sen.j: 安達が原（あだちがはら）

Adachigahara (The Goblin of Adachigahara)

sen.j: - 壬生狂言における代表的演目、日本古劇中の傑作であるとされる。
sen.e: The most representative piece in the Mibu Kyogen repertoire is said to be a masterpiece among the ancient Japanese dramas.
The most representative piece in the Mibu Kyogen repertoire is said to be a masterpiece among the ancient Japanese dramas.
The most representative piece in the Mibu Kyogen repertoire is said to be a masterpiece among the ancient Japanese dramas.

sen.j: 左手が3本指の美女が地蔵尊に詣でて、閼伽（あか）の水をくむ。
sen.e: A beautiful woman who has only three fingers on her left hand visits the Bodhisatva Jizo (guardian deity of children), and scoops up a ladel full of aka no mizu (water to be offered to a Buddha or deity).

A beautiful woman who has only three fingers on her left hand visits the Bodhisatva Jizo (guardian deity of children), and scoops up a ladel full of aka no mizu (water to be offered to a Buddha or deity).

A beautiful woman who has only three fingers on her left hand visits the Bodhisattva Jizo (guardian deity of children), and scoops up a ladle full of aka no mizu (water to be offered to a Buddha or deity).

sen.j: これを見初めた老人（隠居とも大尽とも）が八方、手を尽くしてついには彼女を口説き落とす。
sen.e: An elderly man (both wealthy and retired) who saw this, immediately started making flirtatious small talk with the young woman in an all out effort to seduce her.
An elderly man (both wealthy and retired) who saw this, immediately started making flirtatious small talk with the young woman in an all out effort to seduce her.
An elderly man (both wealthy and retired) who saw this, immediately started making flirtatious small talk with the young woman in an all out effort to seduce her.

sen.j: そこへ老人の妻である醜婦が来て、嫉妬する。
sen.e: The elderly man's wife, an unseemly old woman of ill disposition, arrives on the scene and becomes furious.
The elderly man's wife, an unseemly old woman of ill disposition, arrives on the scene and becomes furious.
The elderly man's wife, an unseemly old woman of ill disposition, arrives on the scene and becomes furious.

sen.j: 老人は妻を蹴倒して若い美女と逃げる。
sen.e: The elderly man kicks his wife, knocking her to the ground, and flees with the young woman.
The elderly man kicks his wife, knocking her to the ground, and flees with the young woman.
The elderly man kicks his wife, knocking her to the ground, and flees with the young woman.

sen.j: 醜婦は鏡を取って化粧してみるが、自分が醜いので自暴自棄に泣き崩れるというあら筋。
sen.e: The old woman lookse in a mirror and starts putting on makeup, but breaks down in tears of despair recognizing her unseemliness.
The old woman lookse in a mirror and starts putting on makeup, but breaks down in tears of despair recognizing her unseemliness.

sen.j: - 4月の大念仏会の公演では、必ず最初に催される演目であり、2月の節分会の際に奉納された炮烙が、この演目の最後に割られる。
sen.e: Horaku wari is always the first piece put on during the April performances of the Dainenbutsu Association, in which the plates donated during the February Setsubun-e are smashed in the finale.

sen.j: 炮烙が割れると願い事が成就するとされている。
sen.e: When the horaku plates are broken, the wish of the person donating the plate comes true.
